title: DBm
text:
dBm or dBmW (decibel-milliwatts) is a unit of <a href="level%20%28logarithmic%20quantity%29">level</a> used to indicate that a power level is expressed in <a href="decibel">decibel</a>s (dB) with reference to one <a href="milliwatt">milliwatt</a> (mW). It is used in radio, microwave and fiber-optical communication networks as a convenient measure of absolute <a href="power%20%28physics%29">power</a> because of its capability to express both very large and very small values in a short form. <a href="dBW">dBW</a> is a similar unit, referenced to one watt (1000 mW).
The decibel (dB) is a <a href="dimensionless%20unit">dimensionless unit</a>, used for quantifying the ratio between two values, such as <a href="signal-to-noise%20ratio">signal-to-noise ratio</a>. The dBm is also dimensionless, but since it compares to a fixed reference value, the dBm rating is an absolute one.
The dBm is not a part of the <a href="International%20System%20of%20Units">International System of Units</a> and therefore is discouraged from use in documents or systems that adhere to SI units (the corresponding SI unit is the watt). However, the unit <a href="decibel">decibel</a> (dB), without the 'm' suffix, is permitted for relative quantities, but not accepted for use directly alongside SI units. 10 dBm may be written 10 dB (1 mW) in SI.
In audio and telephony, dBm is typically referenced relative to a 600-ohm <a href="Electrical%20impedance">impedance</a>, while in radio-frequency work dBm is typically referenced relative to a 50-ohm impedance.
Unit conversions.
A power level of 0 dBm corresponds to a power of 1 milliwatt. A 10 dB increase in level is equivalent to a 10-fold increase in power. Therefore, a 20 dB increase in level is equivalent to a 100-fold increase in power. A 3 dB increase in level is approximately equivalent to doubling the power, which means that a level of 3 dBm corresponds roughly to a power of 2 mW. Similarly, for each 3 dB decrease in level, the power is reduced by about one half, making −3 dBm correspond to a power of about 0.5 mW.

The signal intensity (power per unit area) can be converted to received signal power by multiplying by the square of the wavelength and dividing by 4π (see <a href="Free-space%20path%20loss">Free-space path loss</a>).
In <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Defense">United States Department of Defense</a> practice, <a href="Weighting%20filter">unweighted</a> measurement is normally understood, applicable to a certain <a href="Bandwidth%20%28signal%20processing%29">bandwidth</a>, which must be stated or implied.
In European practice, <a href="psophometric%20weighting">psophometric weighting</a> may be, as indicated by context, equivalent to <a href="dBm0p">dBm0p</a>, which is preferred.
In audio, 0 dBm often corresponds to approximately 0.775 volts, since 0.775 V dissipates 1 mW in a 600 Ω load. The corresponding voltage level is 0 <a href="Decibel%23Voltage">dBu</a>, without the 600 Ω restriction. Conversely, for RF situations with a 50 Ω load, 0 dBm corresponds to approximately 0.224 volts, since 0.224 V dissipates 1 mW in a 50 Ω load.

The dBm was first proposed as an industry standard in the paper "A New Standard Volume Indicator and Reference Level".
